paper_id: Balance of potassium in two long-term field experiments with different fertilization treatments

paper_metadata.title: Balance of potassium in two long-term field experiments with different fertilization treatments
paper_metadata.primary_focus: Potassium balance and related changes in soil K fractions under different long-term fertilization treatments

research_methodology.experimental_design: Long-term stationary field experiments (21 years) at two sites with different soil and climatic conditions. Six fertilization treatments were applied, and three crops were rotated annually.

temporal_scope.data_collection_frequency: Soil samples collected in 1996 (before experiment) and 2017 (end of 7th crop rotation); plant harvest and yield data collected yearly.
temporal_scope.seasonal_coverage: Organic fertilizers applied in autumn (October); mineral P and K applied in autumn; mineral N applied to potatoes and spring barley in spring, and to winter wheat in two split doses (BBCH 21, BBCH 31–32).

spatial_scope.regional_representativeness: The crop rotation corresponds well with intensive farming systems used in the Czech Republic.

sample_design.randomization_approach: Not explicitly stated, but implied by 'stationary field experiments'.
controls_and_treatments: Half dose of farmyard manure + nitrogen in mineral fertilizers (FYM 1/2)
Straw of spring barley + nitrogen in mineral fertilizers (N + ST)

measurement_protocols: Soil samples: air-dried, sieved (≤ 2 mm), collected from 0–30 cm depth.
Plant samples: dried at 40°C, followed by dry decomposition (Mader et al. 1998).
Potassium content in plants: Atomic Adsorption Spectrometry (AA280FS).
CaCl2/DTPA (CAT) extraction: 3.00 g soil + 30 mL 0.01 mol/L CaCl2 and 0.01 mol/L 0.002 DTPA solution, shaken for 1 h, filtered (CSN EN 13651, 2001).
Mehlich 3 extraction: 3.00 g soil + 30 mL solution (0.02 mol/L CH3COOH, 0.25 mol/L NH4NO3, 0.015 mol/L NH4F, 0.013 mol/L HNO3, 0.001 mol/L EDTA), shaken for 5 min, filtered (Mehlich 1984).
Ammonium acetate (NH4OAc) extraction: 3.00 g soil + 30 mL 1 mol/L ammonium acetate solution (pH 7.00), shaken for 2 h, centrifuged (modified Haby et al. 1990).
Boiling HNO3 extraction: 2.5 g finely ground soil + 25 mL 1 mol/L HNO3, heated for 10 min after boiling, cooled for 5 min, filtered, diluted to 100 mL with 0.1 mol/L HNO3 (Helmke and Sparks 2000).
instrumentation: Atomic Adsorption Spectrometry (AA280FS, Agilent Technologies, Mulgrave, Australia) for plant K.
Optical Emission Spectrometer with Inductively Coupled Plasma (ICP-OES, Agilent Technologies 700, Victoria, Australia) for soil extract K.

statistical_approach.significance_testing: Statistical significance was determined, with Pearson's correlation coefficient reported at P < 0.001.
statistical_approach.uncertainty_quantification: Not explicitly stated for all results.
statistical_approach.model_validation: Not applicable for this study type.

primary_measurements.parameter: K recovery rate from farmyard manure by crops
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Observed over 21 years at two sites.

primary_measurements.parameter: K recovery rate from mineral fertilizers by crops

primary_measurements.parameter: K content in wheat straw - Hněvčeves
K content in wheat straw - Humpolec
K content in barley straw - Hněvčeves
K content in barley straw - Humpolec
K content in potato tubers - Hněvčeves

Average K uptake by plants - Humpolec vs Hněvčeves
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Higher K uptake at Humpolec site on average for all variants over 21 years.

temporal_patterns.trend_description: Negative balance for most treatments over 21 years, except for farmyard manure (FYM 1).
Significant tendency to decrease at Hněvčeves (Luvisol) in variants without K fertilization. No significant impact on Kne at Humpolec (Cambisol) over 21 years.
temporal_patterns.trend_significance: Significant at Hněvčeves, not significant at Humpolec.

temporal_patterns.parameter: K content in plough layer (Mehlich 3, Kex, CAT)
temporal_patterns.trend_description: Decreased in all unfertilized variants (Control, N, N+ST) over 21 years. Highest decrease recorded at mineral N fertilization.

comparative_results.practical_significance: Higher K uptake by plants at Humpolec despite lower bioavailable K in soil, possibly due to higher potato yield and better precipitation distribution.
Hněvčeves (200 mg K/kg) had 31% more K than Humpolec (157 mg K/kg).
Hněvčeves (206 mg K/kg) vs Humpolec (153 mg K/kg).
Humpolec (ca. 3000 mg K/kg) had much higher Kne than Hněvčeves (ca. 850 mg K/kg), attributed to soil-forming materials (paragneiss vs loess).

comparative_results.comparison_type: K saturation of CEC between sites
comparative_results.practical_significance: Hněvčeves (4.56%) vs Humpolec (4.37%), indicating similar K saturation despite different CEC values.
Positive balance only with FYM 1; highest negative balance with mineral N fertilization.

geographic_details.elevation: Hněvčeves: 265 m a.s.l.; Humpolec: 525 m a.s.l.

climate_characteristics.climate_classification: Not explicitly stated, but characterized by temperature and precipitation.

precipitation_patterns.Humpolec_distribution: Higher precipitation and its regular distribution throughout the vegetation period.

soil_properties.soil_classification: Hněvčeves: Haplic Luvisol; Humpolec: Stagnic Cambisol
soil_properties.texture: Hněvčeves: Clay loam (4.4% Clay, 77.0% Silt, 18.7% Sand); Humpolec: Sandy loam (5.8% Clay, 43.6% Silt, 50.6% Sand)
soil_properties.mineralogy: Hněvčeves: on loess; Humpolec: on loess on paragneiss (clay mineral type is important for non-exchangeable K).

types: Mineral nitrogen fertilizers (calcium ammonium nitrate, 27% N)
Mineral phosphorus fertilizers (triple super phosphate, 21% P)

FYM_1_3_year_cycle.Hněvčeves: 330 kg N/ha, 90 kg P/ha, 108 kg K/ha (63.0 t fresh FYM/ha)
FYM_1_3_year_cycle.Humpolec: 330 kg N/ha, 382 kg P/ha, 320 kg K/ha (59.45 t fresh FYM/ha)

FYM_1_2_3_year_cycle.Hněvčeves: 165 kg N/ha, 45 kg P/ha, 54 kg K/ha
FYM_1_2_3_year_cycle.Humpolec: 165 kg N/ha, 191 kg P/ha, 160 kg K/ha

rates.N_3_year_cycle: 330 kg N/ha (120 kg N/ha for potatoes, 140 kg N/ha for wheat, 70 kg N/ha for barley)
rates.NPK_3_year_cycle: 330 kg N/ha, 90 kg P/ha, 270 kg K/ha (Potatoes: 120N, 30P, 100K; Wheat: 140N, 30P, 70K; Barley: 70N, 30P, 100K)

N_plus_St_3_year_cycle.N: 330 kg N/ha (120 kg mineral N + straw N for potatoes, 140 kg N/ha for wheat, 70 kg N/ha for barley)
N_plus_St_3_year_cycle.K_from_straw: Hněvčeves: 3.6 kg K/ha; Humpolec: 3.9 kg K/ha
N_plus_St_3_year_cycle.P_from_straw: Hněvčeves: 47 kg P/ha; Humpolec: 56 kg P/ha

timing: Mineral P and K: autumn to each crop.
Mineral N: spring prior to crop establishment for potatoes and spring barley; split doses for winter wheat.

study_timeline.monitoring_frequency: Yearly for plant data, twice over 21 years for soil data.

long_term_trends.trend_direction: Negative for most treatments, positive only for FYM 1.
long_term_trends.projection_timeframe: Not explicitly projected, but implies long-term K deficit.
long_term_trends.sustainability_implications: Annual potassium doses in mineral fertilizers (5–6 kg K/ha) are insufficient for long-term sustainable soil management, leading to K deficit.

long_term_trends.trend_direction: Decrease observed at Hněvčeves (Luvisol) in variants without K fertilization.
long_term_trends.sustainability_implications: Non-exchangeable K is important for replenishing plant-available K, especially at sites with lower potential to release K.

long_term_trends.parameter: K content in plough layer (Mehlich 3, Kex, CAT)
long_term_trends.trend_direction: Decreased in all unfertilized variants (Control, N, N+ST).
long_term_trends.sustainability_implications: Continuous mobilization of K from non-exchangeable bonds helps mitigate observed decreases, but long-term deficits persist.

inter_annual_variability.description: Average yearly nutrient dose from organic fertilizers depended on nutrient content. Yields and K uptake varied between years and sites.

spatial_variability.description: Significant differences in soil properties, yields, K uptake, and K fractions between Hněvčeves and Humpolec sites.

methodological_strengths: Long-term (21 years) field experiments provide robust data on K dynamics.
Study conducted at two sites with contrasting soil and climatic conditions, enhancing generalizability.
Comprehensive analysis of K fractions (bioavailable, exchangeable, non-exchangeable) using multiple extraction methods.
Comparison of different fertilization treatments, including organic and mineral sources.
methodological_limitations: K content in the subsoil was not considered in the balance calculation, which could be a significant K source for plants.
Not all non-exchangeable K is immediately available to plants, as it is released continuously over many years.
Specific p-values for all ANOVA results are not provided, only general statements of statistical significance.
data_quality_assessment.data_completeness: High for the parameters studied, with detailed quantitative results provided in tables and text.

representativeness.spatial_representativeness: Two sites represent different soil-climatic conditions within the Czech Republic.
representativeness.temporal_representativeness: 21-year duration provides insights into long-term trends and sustainability.
representativeness.system_representativeness: Crop rotation and farming practices are representative of intensive farming systems in the Czech Republic.

uncertainty_sources: Potential for K mobilization from subsoil not accounted for in balance.
validation_evidence: High correlation (Pearson's r > 0.95) between Mehlich 3 and NH4OAc extraction methods for K content, suggesting consistency.

key_methodological_references: Haby et al. (1990) - Ammonium acetate extraction
Helmke and Sparks (2000) - Boiling HNO3 extraction
Mader et al. (1998) - Dry ashing of biological materials
comparative_studies: Blake et al. (1999) - K content, uptake, and balance in European long-term experiments.
Liu et al. (2010) - Long-term effect of fertilizers on soil properties.
Srinivasarao et al. (2014) - Potassium release characteristics and balance in long-term experiments.
Øgaard and Krogstad (2005) - Soil extraction methods to predict K release.
Binner et al. (2017) - CAT extraction sensitivity to clay sorbents.
literature_integration.theoretical_framework: Potassium cycling in soils, plant uptake mechanisms (soil solution, exchangeable K, non-exchangeable K), rhizosphere processes (H+ excretion, K release), K fixation by clay minerals (2:1 types, mica, vermiculite).
benchmarking_data: Official assessment of K pool in CR for loamy soils ('satisfactory pool' or 'good pool').
Comparison of non-exchangeable K contents with other long-term sites (Bad Lauchstadt, Rothamsted, Norway).

extraction_metadata.data_richness_assessment: The paper is rich in quantitative data, particularly regarding potassium fractions, balance, and soil properties across different fertilization treatments and sites.
potential_ambiguities: Specific p-values for all ANOVA results are not provided, only general statements of 'statistically significant differences'.
Exact sample sizes for all measurements (e.g., plant harvests) are not explicitly detailed beyond soil replications.
extraction_limitations: Inability to extract specific p-values for all statistical comparisons due to their absence in the text.
recommended_validation_checks: Verify all numerical values against the original paper's tables and figures.
Confirm units for all quantitative data.
